title: Continuous versions of dbinom and dpois
text: following code shows usefulness dbinom_continuous(k, n, p), dpois3_continuous(k, n, p) dpois_continuous(x, lambda).
code: library(binompoiscont) ## Suppose we do 10.3 trials with a probability of success of 0.3, and we ## want to know the probability that the sum of the successes ## is 3.5. n <- 10.3 k <- 3.5 p <- 0.3  ## If we use the dbinom() function we get an error: computer says no, can't do this. dbinom(k, n, p) #> [1] NaN  ## The same for the dpois() function. dpois(k, n * p) #> [1] 0  ## But this probability can be calculated with the continuous versions. dbinom_continuous(k, n, p) #> [1] 0.2457182 dpois3_continuous(k, n, p) #> [1] 0.2028806 dpois_continuous(k, n * p) #> [1] 0.2028806
